Disruptive as television and radio can be to traditional concepts of education, and
many educationists, if fully used by education, we believe that they will be
resisted by some as long as possible. Certain early efforts in the use of tele¬
vision for education, based principally on saving teachers, space and money
(although they do have a usefulness to do these things too) rather than on improving
education, have already created a climate of resistance hi some quarters which can
be overcome only with the utmost of understanding and cooperation„
Such a meeting as proposed here would of course be very similar in many
respects to several of the seminars listed in the present grant request itself. And
it is our hope that some or all of those attending this initial conference for others,
whom they, the KAEB and the Foundation might mutually suggest), if the project
were to be approved, might serve as an advisory committee throughout its term.
One of the first of the other meetings listed in the proposed budget below would
involve assembling the best authorities available from other organisations in the
natural and social sciences, humanities and education areas, with representatives
from UNESCO and others with related experience and broad background, to begin
the intensive study and testing necessary to establish eventual qualification
categories koi membership in the NAEB as a professional association, which .is
the second and parallel half of the development visualized in this proposal.
To discuss this professional development effort briefly: It will be noted
that the individual membership of the NAEB, being a relatively new category, now
numbers only some 300 individuals. Progress is so far slow in view of the diffi¬
